Those remaining in the New Orleans Superdome have seen conditions inside deteriorate steadily since thousands arrived there on Monday fleeing the rising waters of Katrina.
Ann Gerhart is a reporter with The Washington Post who's spent some time inside the Superdome Wednesday.
She joins us now by phone from Baton Rouge, the capital of Louisiana.
Good to have you back on TALK OF THE NATION, Ann.
Oh, happy to be here, I guess.

What was it like inside the Superdome?
Well, it's very hot, it's muggy, it's quite dark.
Conditions there had deteriorated steadily since Monday when the power went out and the plumbing broke down.
So there's no running water.
The toilets are overflowing.
It's a frightening place, and people are quite miserable.
There's been no effort or ability to communicate with them.
So rumors run rampant in a crowd of 15,000 people desperate for information.
And I couldn't ever take more than a few steps before someone would reach out and clutch at me and say, `Miss, are you from FEMA?
Miss, are you from the city?
And, you know, it was just this sort of heartbreaking situation.
I mean, I saw a woman cradling her tiny baby in a diaper.
I said, `How old is your baby?
She said, `Two weeks,' you know.

And you know, there just didn't seem to be any plan in place whatsoever, not just for the Superdome but for New Orleans in general, as we are beginning to, I think finally, all recognize, you know, several days after this storm came through.
It must--obviously, with no power, it was dark.
When you say it was frightening, did you feel physically threatened?
I didn't feel physically threatened, no. I have to say, most people came to me hoping I could help them in some way.

And when I told them I was a reporter, you know, they wanted to tell their stories very much, and they hoped that if I knew someone on the outside, could I please call and say that they were in there?
And, you know, I wrote down some cell numbers and, you know, said that I would try to get through.
I do think, however, that to stay there for a period of days would feel dangerous.
I mean, it was a chaotic situation and it seemed to have organized itself in the way that humans instantly do.
The very first layer had its own structure.
There were boys playing soccer on the field.
I did run across one boy who said that he lived in the projects where he played football, and he never thought he'd be playing football in the Superdome.
So the resilience of children could be seen there in that first level.
And families had set up their personal space and had boundaries and kept it neat.
And, you know, the picnic cooler was at one end and the children's toys were at another, and the clean diapers were clustered at a third end.
And then as you ascended into the more darker and scarier reaches of the Superdome, you could feel that all begin to break down on the second level where all the toilets were.
The floor was just slick with human excrement mixed with urine because no one could go in the bathrooms any longer.
They were just that fetid.
And so people would just try to find a space for themselves that they thought was a little away where they could relieve themselves.

And on the third level where the skyboxes were, it seemed like some people would disappear into dark rooms to abandon themselves to whatever it was that they thought might, you know, amuse them or content them during this time.
There was an ersatz speakeasy that someone had somehow gotten into a keg of beer, and, you know, if you knew where it was, you could go get your water bottle filled.
One man told me he had lost everything, and, you know, he was happy to be able to find a little beer.
And then up on the fourth level, in the most nether reaches, there were--that was where all the women said, `You don't go up there.
You know, they wouldn't let their children go up there.

That was where the bogeyman lived, essentially, and all the rumors that were existent about there's somebody stealing babies, there's someone raping girls--that's--they seemed to flow from this sense that up there in the darkest regions was where the real problem was.
And the National Guard spokesman for the area assured me that none of that had happened and that none of that was true.
But we do know how to do it.

But in that kind of environment, I think, where people are completely absent any information and perceive that day after day goes by and they don't get any help, I think it breeds that kind of fear and anxiety and eventually misery.

So it was going to always be a very lengthy process.
